title: Get​
content: </> Stellar.Get( name: string, dontInit: boolean? ) → any Retrieves a singular file loaded with Stellar by its name

title: BulkGet​
content: </> Stellar.BulkGet(...: string) → {ModuleScript } Retrieves multiple loaded with Stellar by its name. Useful for starting services when the client/server first runs

title: Load​
content: </> Stellar.Load(module: ModuleScript ) → () Loads a singular file into Stellar

title: BulkLoad​
content: </> Stellar.BulkLoad(...: Folder ) → () Loads multiple files into Stellar at once

title: Library​
content: </> Stellar.Library(name: string) → any Retrieves a wally package by name

title: MarkAsLoaded​
content: deprecated in v2 </> This was deprecated in v2 Function will not error so existing code still works. Please implement your own solution Stellar.MarkAsLoaded() → ()

title: OnLoadingCompletion​
content: deprecated in v2 </> This was deprecated in v2 Function will be called so existing code still works. Please implement your own solution Stellar.OnLoadingCompletion(func: () → ()) → ()

title: new​
content: </> Scheduler.new(loopTime: number) → Scheduler Create a new Scheduler object

title: Start​
content: </> Scheduler:Start() → () Begin running tasks

title: Tick​
content: </> Scheduler:Tick(func: () → ()) → RBXScriptConnection  Add a task to the Scheduler

title: Destroy​
content: </> Scheduler:Destroy() → () Destory and disable the Scheduler

title: SoundFX
content: On this page SoundFX A simplistic way to store and play sound effects Sounds must be stored in ReplicatedStorage inside a folder called "SoundFXs" You can (and advised) to store sounds in subfolders if you have a large amount

title: ObserveSignal​
content: </> Network:ObserveSignal( name: string, func: ( player: Player , ...any ) → () ) → RBXScriptConnection  Observes a RemoteEvent

title: Signal​
content: </> Network:Signal( name: string, ...: any ) → () Signals the server if run on the client, and vice versa The second argument must be the player to signal if being run on the server

title: SignalAll​
content: This item only works when running on the server. Server </> Network:SignalAll( name: string, ...: any ) → () Signals all clients

title: SignalAsync​
content: </> Network:SignalAsync( name: string, ...: any ) → () Signals and yields for response

title: Invoke​
content: This item only works when running on the client. Client </> Network:Invoke( name: string, ...: any ) → any Invokes the server

title: InvokePromise​
content: This item only works when running on the client. Client </> Network:InvokePromise( name: string, ...: any ) → any Invokes the server with a promise

title: OnInvoke​
content: This item only works when running on the server. Server </> Network:OnInvoke( name: string, func: ( player: Player , ...any ) → () ) → () Sets the function for handling invoke requests

title: Reserve​
content: This item only works when running on the server. Server </> Network:Reserve(...: any) → () Used to reserve remotes on the server. When remotes arent used or listened to on the server, they cannot be created. By reserving them, they are created so the client can connect to them. Example Usage: Network:Reserve( {"ExampleFunction", "RemoteFunction"}, {"ExampleEvent", "RemoteEvent"} )

title: GetEndpoint​
content: </> Network:GetEndpoint( name: string, remote: Endpoint ) → Remote Used internally for getting remotes. You should use this too if you need to use the physical remote as they are named GUIDs after first found on client. This practice, whilst not completely solving remote tampering, will make it slightly harder.

title: Getting Started
content: Getting Started

title: Should I use Stellar?​
content: I don't know, up to you.
